title: FirstFT: Weakened Boris Johnson survives no-confidence vote
text:
The British prime minister, Boris Johnson, has survived a bruising no-confidence vote, but his victory by a 211 to 148 ballot of Conservative party MPs left him badly damaged and exposed the scale of divisions and animosity among them.

The result meant that more than 40 per cent of Johnson's MPs wanted to oust the prime minister, a revolt that was far more serious than Downing Street had expected.

The result of the vote, which had been triggered after more than 15 per cent of the party's MPs withdrew their support, was, as our UK chief political commentator, Robert Shrimsley writes, “as bad a result as any victory can be”. However, this morning, Johnson was attempting to unite his cabinet around his faltering leadership, insisting that the victory was “extremely good”.

  • Go deeper: History shows that incumbents struggle to regain their standing once MPs turn on them in large numbers.

To read more on British politics sign up to our Inside Politics newsletter. Thanks for reading FirstFT Americas. Here's the rest of today's news.

Five more stories in the news

1. SEC chair to set out overhaul of US equity market The Securities and Exchange Commission is exploring an overhaul of US stock market rules to strengthen competition and ensure individual investors are fairly treated after the explosion in retail trading during the pandemic. Gary Gensler, SEC chair, is said to have settled on several potential proposals, including the creation of an auction system designed to increase competition between services. He is expected to outline some of the plans at an industry conference tomorrow.

2. Elon Musk threatens to abandon Twitter takeover The Tesla chief executive has threatened to walk away from his $44bn acquisition of the social media company, accusing it of being in “clear material breach” by failing to provide enough information about fake accounts.

3. US investors rebel against high executive pay A growing number of investors are rebelling against high pay at the top of the biggest US companies with some starting to target individual board directors to try to force action. Some companies have begun postponing their say-on-pay votes until after their annual meeting to try to win support from shareholders, writes Patrick Temple-West.

4. LA mayoral race set to come down to two candidates The race for Los Angeles mayor is expected to narrow to a contest between California congresswoman Karen Bass and billionaire property  developer Rick Caruso following today's primary elections, according to a recent poll, amid growing debate over how to tackle rising crime in the city. Bass leads the field of candidates seeking to replace Eric Garcetti, who cannot seek re-election due to term limits. If elected in November's general election, she would be the first black woman to serve as the city's mayor.

5. Apple to offer ‘buy now, pay later' credit The iPhone maker is jumping into the “buy now, pay later” market in a challenge to fintech companies such as Klarna and Affirm which are already grappling with investor pressure, slower ecommerce growth and rising interest rates.

The war in Ukraine:

  • Calls for ceasefire are ‘premature': Estonia's prime minister, Kaja Kallas, has criticised “premature calls for a ceasefire” in Ukraine by other EU leaders, saying the bloc has to be “prepared for a long war”.

  • Military developments: Russian advances have made it “very, very difficult” for Ukraine to win the war, according to one of Kyiv's top security officials.

  • Oil and gas: As Russia's energy isolation intensifies, with foreign partners exiting and exports down, what's next for the country's most important industry?

  • Opinion: The current global moment resembles a return of the cold war more than the threat of a third world war, writes Gideon Rachman.

The day ahead

Nato in the Baltics The transatlantic alliance hosts a press event to discuss Exercise Ramstein Legacy, a long-planned test of missile defence capabilities across Poland, Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia.

WTO meeting A ministerial meeting of the World Trade Organization's general council begins in Geneva, with discussions to focus on intellectual property barriers for Covid-19 medicines, among other topics.

Economic data The US publishes its April consumer credit and trade deficit figures. Chile's central bank is expected to raise the country's benchmark interest rate.

Belgian royals visit Democratic Republic of Congo King Philippe and Queen Mathilde will make the first visit of a Belgian royal couple to the country in 12 years, which is expected to include a long-awaited apology over Belgium's colonial past.

Don't miss our brilliant event, the Global Boardroom. Today has already seen FT editor Roula Khalaf interview Ukraine's president Volodymyr Zelenskyy, and later highlights include Iván Duque, president of the Republic of Colombia, in conversation with Michael Stott, FT Latin America editor. What else we're reading

Why are we all working so hard? In spite of — or perhaps because of — new technology, people say they are working harder to tighter deadlines under greater levels of tension. This intensification of work doesn't seem to be making us richer, but it does appear to be making us sicker, writes Sarah O'Connor.

Taiwan: preparing for a potential Chinese invasion President Xi Jinping's ambitions and the modernisation of China's military are raising fears of an attempt to annex the island. With the war in Ukraine serving as a wake-up call, here's how Taipei is getting ready for military action.

‘Liquidity is terrible' Traders' ability to seamlessly buy and sell stocks, bonds and other financial products on Wall Street has deteriorated sharply this year, adding fuel to the big swings on the world's biggest and deepest capital markets. Liquidity across US markets is now at its worst level since the early days of the pandemic and the fraught conditions have collided with a big shift in the global economy that has caught many portfolio managers off-guard.

‘Buy now, pay later' must be regulated The business model has boomed during Covid-19 as people diverted spending to retail and shopped more online. But sceptics have reason to be cynical over the robustness of BNPL, writes Patrick Jenkins.

Egypt looks to local farmers Soaring grain prices in the wake of Russia's invasion of Ukraine have underscored the importance of the local wheat market in Egypt, the world's biggest grain importer. As global supplies tighten, Egypt's government is determined to get its hands on as much of this year's crop as it can.

Music

The first gift “Lost Highway” gave popular culture was its title. Michael Hann explains how the classic song, which somehow seems both ancient and modern, became claimed equally by country and rock. Find out its history — and listen to a host of different interpretations.
